2.text:
“Oh I’m so fat.”
“So is your boyfriend really fat as well?”

9.text:
“You’re not fat.”
I know when people say that they’re quite

15.text:
clearly lying to me.
I am fat. I am obese and my BMI is quite high

21.text:
and if you can’t see that you need a stronger
pair of spectacles.

25.text:
It goes back to the fact that people are uncomfortable
with that word.

28.text:
Yeah, with the F word, the dreaded F word.
The word ‘fat’ isn’t insulting to me,

32.text:
so don’t try and come in and swoosh in like
a knight in shining armour and go, “You’re

38.text: not fat! You’re gorgeous! You’re fine!”

41.text:
“You’ll never get a partner if you look
like that.”

44.text:
My mum thought that any date I went on, the
guy, had to have a fetish about fat girls.

49.text:
Oh God!
“Oh he’s good looking. What did you do?

52.text:
Are you a really good cook? Is he weird? Has
he got a fetish? Does he like fat people?”

55.text:
“Has he got a fetish?”
“Does he jiggle you?”

58.text:
You can see people when you’re grocery shopping
looking into your basket. And the shopkeeper

63.text:
will just be like…
You know when people praise you for eating

69.text:
a salad. “Oh are you eating… Well done
you’re eating a salad!”

74.text:
“Should you be wearing that?”
I hear this all the time.

77.text:
Do you?
Yes, but it’s nothing to do with being fat.

81.text:
Why is there this preconception that there’s
things, that because you’re a certain size

84.text:
you shouldn’t be able to wear.
It’s because of the Fat Girl Rule Book.

87.text:
Horizontal stripes - you shouldn’t wear
that.

88.text:
We shouldn’t wear anything that shows your
arms.

91.text:
Shouldn’t wear anything fitted.
I just love that so many women are coming

94.text:
together to actually show their middle finger,
and say, “Kiss my middle finger. I don’t

98.text:
care. I’m not going to stick the rules that
you have set out for me and I’m going to

102.text:
wear whatever the hell I want to.”
People expect that you should be dressing

105.text:
to a certain code so you hide yourself and
disguise yourself in the background. “Don’t

110.text:
make a show of yourself fatty, because you
need to know your place.”

114.text:
“Have you tried exercise?”
For me it makes me feel good mentally. Like,

122.text:
if I’ve had a bad week or a bad day, I’ll
go to the gym or go and swim to swim it out,

126.text:
clear my head. And I feel great. Not because
I want to be a certain size or look a certain

130.text:
way, or want a certain number on the scales.
I just do it because I enjoy it.

135.text:
So if someone says, “Have you tried exercise?”
like it’s some sort of remedy to my fatness,

141.text:
then no, I haven’t tried exercise to shed
myself of my blubby body.

147.text:
They’re trying to be nice but if just comes
across as very passive aggressive. “Oh no

151.text:
but I really care. Are you worried about your
health?” No, you’re just being a dickhead.

155.text:
It really annoys me when people obviously
assume that you’re going to be really unhealthy

158.text:
just by physically looking at you. Like for
example, me, I’ve been a strict vegetarian

161.text:
since birth, I don’t smoke, I’ve never
drank in my life, how much more healthy of

165.text:
a life style could I lead?
I guess I am worried about my health. You

170.text:
know, the whole diabetes... being able to
move in the future, yeah. But isn’t everyone

179.text:
worried about their health?
I think when we start going down that route

181.text:
of asking people, we have to then start going
down the route of, walking though pubs and

186.text:
everyone having a pint, “Do you worry about
your health?” Or everyone smoking on the

190.text:
street, “Do you worry about your health?”
People are so concerned with other people’s

193.text:
lives and their health, that they actually
forget that they need to be concentrating

197.text:
on themselves.
That’s it. I’ll leave that to my doctor

199.text:
thanks.
Yeah exactly, a qualified G.P.

201.text:
I had that shouted at me from a car while
I was running. I was like, I’m trying, I’m

211.text:
running!
Are you expecting that person to be like,

213.text:
“Good point weirdo in a car. I’m going
to go to a gym now.”

217.text:
Fat is the one thing you’re allowed to have
a go at about people.

220.text:
Like, you know, a white van driver just shouted
out at you, “Fat!”. You tell that to your

224.text:
story to your friends, they’ll just laugh
and they go, “Yeah, you are a bit overweight

230.text:
“Imagine how good looking you’d be if
you lost a bit of weight.”

235.text:
I don’t think the world is ready for that.
Then it’s like, “Imagine how much of a

239.text:
nice person you’d be if you weren’t such
a massive prick.”

242.text:
Beauty is what’s within. You can be a size
ten and be a vicious, venomous bitch. And

249.text:
that’s not pretty.
I’m both. They don’t cancel each other

253.text: out. I can be fat, I can be beautiful. I am.

259.text:
I can be fat, I can be beautiful, I can be
delusional if I’m Naomi.
